Award.AwardTitle: Enhancement of the Paleontology Research Collection at the University of Montana
Award.AbstractNarration: An award has been made to the University of Montana under the direction of Dr. George D. Stanley to acquire new metal cabinets for the collection of Bear Gulch fossil biota of central Montana. This collection contains important fossils of vertebrates, invertebrates, plants and algae that is unique in its composition and in the retention of original colors by many of the fossils. The diversity of materials adds to our understanding of ancient climates on the planet. The project will replace older oak cabinets, which are known to produce acid vapors that cause deterioration of the fossil rock material and destroy their scientific value. The collection will be re-housed in cabinets in a mobile compactor system that will improve the physical accessibility of the collection for researchers and students. The specimens will be catalogued, photographed, and the images and associated data will be made available online and through the web site called PaleoPortal. Students will be employed in the project and will be trained in the practice of paleontological curation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The University of Montana Paleontology Center (UMPC) is a university research center containing over 100,000 fossils representing the USA, Canada, Mexico and many countries overseas. This project helped enhance the most important fossil collection in the UMPC holdings– the Carboniferous age Bear Gulch (BG) biota of central Montana. It is one of the most important fossil deposits in the world because of the exceptional preservation of an entire diverse ecological community (vertebrates, invertebrates, plants and algae), including soft animal body parts. The collection helps reveal the diversity of Carboniferous life. This project centered on an orphaned collection of the Bear Gulch received from Indiana University but also included the entire BG collection, including the type and other vouchered specimens, which formed the basis for 138 scientific publications.The valuable Bear Gulch collection at UM suffered from limited storage space, humidity and storage in old oak cabinets which were degrading many valuable specimens. There also existed a need to make these valuable collection more accessable for study and research.

The project work elements included: 1) cataloging and curation of the orphaned BG collection as well and the uncurated material, 2) purchase of scanners and computers, 3) the Installation of a compactor system to increase storage capacity, 4) transfer of specimens in oak cabinets into new metal cases in the compactor system, 5) scanning and photographing the specimens and 6) making the collection data available to a wider audience. This was accomplished by development of an interactive website:

http://www.cas.umt.edu/paleontology/

which includes digital photos and can be accessed by anyone from anywhere in the world. The site also includes outreach and education activities. The project utilized a workforce that included the P.I., a full time collections manager, graduate students, undergraduate students and many volunteers who assisted in the project.

The results of the project improved the usefulness of the BG collection to better support the infrastructure of paleobiology and the database and web site will enhance the support of science for many years, assuring the timely dissemination of knowledge. Finally, the training of graduate and undergraduate students involved in the project assisted in their educational and professional development. Although the Bear Gulch collection resides in rural Montana, far from urban centers, it can nevertheless have a broad impact on the science community at both national and international levels.
